positive.review:
As a long-time player, I‚Äôll say: it‚Äôs worth it, but not without some reservations.

For anyone coming back after years away, or stepping into the franchise for the first time, the Definitive Edition delivers a great way to experience one of the most iconic RTS titles of its era, with modern compatibility and all content bundled. I had plenty of fun revisiting the campaigns, re-engaging with the factions, and simply enjoying that old-school strategy feeling that i loved as a kid.

However veterans who already know the ins and outs of the original, you won‚Äôt find earth-shattering changes here. The ‚Äúdefinitive‚Äù label might raise expectations of a full overhaul, but what you get is more of a well-polished restoration. Whether it‚Äôs worth the price to YOU comes down to how much YOU value nostalgia, smoother performance, and easier modding over new gameplay features.

As of this review they do have a team that is actively patching bugs(Old and New) and correcting other issues so that's a plus

I‚Äôd give it roughly 8/10 from where I sit now: solid, fun, spiritually intact, but not transformational.

Playing the remaster of one of my favourite games is amazing. The first 20 hours in was good and was confused about the graphics as it looked like the same the original, Until I discovered my settings were set to low, once I realised this error I switched the graphics to top tier and thats when I experienced the 'remaster' of the game. Playing the original campaign and winter assault was good, but the x factor is dark crusade. I'm almost completed the story for all the factions which has been amazing so far. Just some tips before you purchase this remaster, don't play Necrons if this is your first time playing the game, because they are slow - wait until you've played a couple of factions. Don't go in expecting sc2 graphics, but if you're in for the nostalgia experience, then this game is for you. When I first learned about the remaster, I was hoping they would include Tyranids as a surprise, but that didn't happen. I give this remaster 9/10. If Tyranids were included, I would have raised it to 11.

The RTS genre has died since the glory days in the 00's. Some games like Iron Harvest try to capture the same magic, but most seem too preoccupied with changing, adding or "simplifying" mechanics to the point that Starcraft 2 is still mainstream today because it just hasn't tried to fix what isn't broken, and hasn't faced competition. 

The original Dawn of War is, and always has been the pinnacle of RTS design in my opinion. From playing it religiously in my youth since launch day to still firing up a campaign every few months in my 30's, nothing matches the incredible squad and upgrade mechanics and balance of resource management. The pacing is perfect, not devolving into early game pure aggression, but not turning into a 4x of late-game deployment either. It's not uncommon to build all the buildings in an average match, even when trying to win fast.

The only downside to the original Dawn of War has always been the pathing. Large groups of units or multiple selected squads would move weirdly, traffic jams were common, and units would choose strange distances to stand at when firing. This definitive edition is an incredible execution of "if it ain't broke, don't fix it"! They didn't change a single thing except for the pathing, and modernizing the UI scaling, audio quality, texture resolution and world lighting. Heck, they even kept the original cinematic scream after initially changing it to a dialogue line because feedback craved the original.

They even preserved mod support! 10/10, refreshed something that was already close to perfect, and that nobody was asking for, at a great price with great reward for loyalty.

I have over 1000 hours in the original and I was a modder on several mods.  This game is an exploitative, small, uninspired update to what once was one of the greatest RTS games of all time.  After falling flat on their face, making DoW 3, Relic returns one last time to put in the least amount of work possible to shovel out a title that they can charge money for.  No real graphics upgrades. No real animation, unit pathing or AI upgrades.  Mod support remains but, really, so what?  It's present in the original offering and that still works fine, thanks to the tireless work of the community.  

DoW wasn't special because Relic made it so but because it had the good sense to get out of the way and let the community create one of the greatest, most pervasive mod landscapes in gaming.  With this title, Relic basically took an old automobile, didn't perform a tune-up, didn't clean up or patch up any of the rough edges, and just gave it a rushed paint job, and wheeled it out at 66% of full price ... 20 years later.

An embarrassment.  Who is this game for? 

Not worth your time.  There are better versions of this game available for far less. 

6/10.

This "definitive" edition is anything but. The graphics are a bit better, but nothing is playing right. Everything is a bit off when playing this game. Units don't really obey your commands. This kinda sucks to be honest, I really don't know how you can't upgrade a game this old and simple and mess it up, but here we are.

[H1] Cash-grab, not a labour of love [/h1]
64 bit integration is a fantastic addition, and there are lofty promises of mod support and tools (that have yet to be materialised). Despite the 64 bit, the game runs poorly and there doesn't seem to have been any improvements to performance. Game is riddled with bugs and issues that never existed in the originals. Bug-fixing lists issues as solved, only for them to remain or worsen after yet another patch.
[h3] A plethora of bugs [/h3]
[list]
[*]Units barely doing damage while pursuing moving targets
[*]Transports leaving units stranded on impassable terrain
[*]Grenade abilities that end up doing nothing
[*]Questionable AI pathing
[*]Flickering textures
[*]Broken campaign AI
[*]Jump units fail to do so, but use up their "energy", or are returned to where they started.
[*]Unit portraits flicker between new additions and old shitty upscaled versions
[*]Sync-kills on units that aren't supposed to happen (Squiggoth sync-killing a rhino transport like it was infantry)
[/list]
To name a few.
[h3] Cheap AI upscale [/h3]
Lazy upscaling, applied haphazardly to all the textures in the game, seems to have been little to no quality control as the textures are everything from good looking, to mediocre, to oddly washed out and produces a jarring visual mess on certain unit models. Unit portraits were released in such a poor state that they looked worse than the originals, and have subsequently been updated post-launch after having taken our money.
[h3] Busted campaigns [/h3]
[list]
[*]Soulstorm campaigns are missing their ending cinematics
[*]Patches have repeatedly bricked and bugged out old saves
[*]Currently the Dark Crusade campaign AI does nothing but idle
[*]Iconic voice lines and quips during stronghold missions cut short by unit response sounds
[*]In-game cinematics failing to animate properly due to bugs
[*]Game breaking bugs barring progress in the original DoW campaign because of a bug related to jumping units
[/list]
[h3] That was then, this is now [/h3]
Currently, as it stands, this version of DoW is a hard pass. It remains to be seen if the developers stick to this game for long enough to iron out all the bugs and perhaps improve performance. A more apt name would be "definitively broken edition". The few improvements provided do not make up for the additional bugs, and the frustrating experience of playing the campaigns during these rounds of patches that break your progress. Clearly Relic is only interested in fleecing its fans with releasing anniversary editions and now lazy "definitive" editions in quick succession for DoW and Space Marine. So far, neither provide a "definitive" version of the game to play, but are instead splitting the already small player-base further.
Still able to shoot through cover, crappy graphics, and janky controls. Why the hell did I purchase this game again?

Relic entertainment with their big brains have finally done it! They managed to make a definitive edition of the greatest RTS of all time with almost zero efforts! After a full day of "hard working", they slapped a 29.99$ before went to bed. They promised us that they will stay faithful to the original and they did. Everything from original DOW are all here including problems and bugs. That's what I call a faithful remastered!

The main reasons that made me bought this version are the new promising pathfinding system and more modding support. Now that I've ran out of copium. Let's see what makes this a negative review.
[list] 
[*]In the ORI ver; the big battle looks awkward and it's hard to micro units efficiently since they will try not to step on each other toes. The DEF ver. fixes these issues by removing the fucking unit occlusions, now you can have 2 tanks or three rhinos humping each other in the glorius HD. Soulstorm seems to fix this but for other modes, nope. 

[*]Melee battles respond so much better in DEF. But since you can phase through friendly units, results in a weird disengage or double engages. Instead of fighting one at a time in a tight space, now you'll have 2 or sometimes 3 squads orgies. Occasionally one of them will just say "I'mma do my own thing" before marathon 2 kilos passing through the orgies to disrupt your backline, his squads are still fighting with the frontline btw.

  Or one unit of your squad got body blocked by the enemies during retreat, instead of just leave him there. The rest will now run back in a circle, so they can regroup with the lost one. Semper Fi, I guess? The solution to this is to keep commanding them to retreat until that lost one is dead (In ORI I just simply retreat with ease).

[*]What about units stuck into terrains or to each other? Yeah, still there. If you're unlucky then you'll have to delete the entire squad since they won't move until Larry can get out of the creek. I only have to do this once in ORI but somehow DEF manages to surpass that.

[*]Air units sucked in Ori visually and gameplay wise, it looks like they tried not to fly above the ground units so they ended up in janky movements. In DEF, they still sucked but in HD. 

[*]Transporter units often refused to take any passengers unless you managed to find the correct meridian angle. And when you unload them there are 50/50 chance that some units will fuse with the transporter, forcing you to load/unload again. I only encounter this once in MP (Soulstorm). But in SP campaigns, it happened a lot to the point I don't even bother using them (except in SS). 

[*]Cutscenes still glitch to this day. Where there're supposed to be events and voicelines, they simply skip it. ORI is still fine even with mods so I don't know why.

[*]Campaign bugs still persist including the infamous end mission crashes. This is wild, I've never thought I will see bugsplats again. SS in ORI is not stable at all and require mods to fix the problem. It seems that I'll have to wait for modders to do Relic's job again.

[*]Game expansions and it's rules: They decided to combine every expansions into one launcher and for that I must thank you. But what's the point of combining them, if you can't change the game rules and force the players to only play SS rule in MP. If you not gonna change it then please fix the goddamn awful aerial systems.

[*]Shadow: Your unit shadows will skywalk in SP and MP, must be the work of warp trickery or just another ignored problem. This one isn't presence in ORI so thanks for the new feature, I guess?

[*]Zoom and color: A little bit further is not what I can call an improvement. Even with the maximum zoom out, it's still not that good for big battles which happen a lot more than you think. Combined with some map extra saturated color, you will have almost zero visibility when max zoom out. The mod from ORI does fix this issue with more zoom options. But come on, It's so tiresome to see that they can't do it properly and have to rely on modders. 
  
[*]Visual upgrade: Yes, overall it's better than ORI which is 20 years old now. But it seemed they heavily relied on the AI upscale to the point that the sprites, face and some body models are so bad when compare to ORI. It's not "pixelated bad", it's uncanny and scuffed bad. On initial launch ver. it was so bad to the point that I've to play ORI again just to prove that I was not hallucinating. There's no way any veterans see DEF and said my man Gabriel's face looked better than ORI and really didn't look like he was wearing a human leather face. They've fixed this but still how did you even let this happended at first place? Is it that hard to hire artists to smooth the final products before release? Where's the QC team? 

[*]Framerate shouldn't become a problem since they upgraded the game to a newer engine, but in a big fight I sometimes get a significant drop. Don't know why, It's a vanilla and not crazy mods like UA/Uni, runs on SSD with plenty rooms to spare. I chose not to play UA in ORI because in a fullscale war, it ended up with not enjoyable/massive stutters. Why does the new one stutter from a 3 vs 3 that's not even at pop cap?

[*]For modding
There's no dedicated mod page in the game or the community except the Mod UI in the menu. You want mods? Go find it yourself, loser LMAO. This doesn't encourage the new players to install mods at all. 
Yes, they did it right by saying DEF will support more modding by providing more tools and playgrounds which is superb for all the modders. I just hope the game will actually be able to handle that much craziness in the near future but considering DOW IV is coming out next year, I've lost faith. I feel like this definitive is a nostalgic-bait made purely to cash grab older players by the balls. Todd Howard would be proud of your work.
[/list]
[h1]*TLDR*[/h1];
- [b]Lazy[/b] is what I will define this version on initial launch, a month passed by and it's still a half-assed remastered of a 20 years-old game. Yes there're patches that fix things later on and all these for me, are minor-mid inconveniences that I can simply ignore. But considered that I paid 26.99$ for this. I just can't gives a thumbs up for now.

I still recommend the new players to buy this game with a heavy discount. The game is good because the foundation is just that good. DEF does make some aspects much better than ORI. But definitely not for a full price. 
Overpromise and underdeliver shouldn't be reward with more money than it actually deserved.
Instead use your money to support the modders that keep doing the god emperor's work for all of us players. May the emperor protects them!

I have over 1000 hours in the original and I was a modder on several mods.  This game is an exploitative, small, uninspired update to what once was one of the greatest RTS games of all time.  After falling flat on their face, making DoW 3, Relic returns one last time to put in the least amount of work possible to shovel out a title that they can charge money for.  No real graphics upgrades. No real animation, unit pathing or AI upgrades.  Mod support remains but, really, so what?  It's present in the original offering and that still works fine, thanks to the tireless work of the community.  

DoW wasn't special because Relic made it so but because it had the good sense to get out of the way and let the community create one of the greatest, most pervasive mod landscapes in gaming.  With this title, Relic basically took an old automobile, didn't perform a tune-up, didn't clean up or patch up any of the rough edges, and just gave it a rushed paint job, and wheeled it out at 66% of full price ... 20 years later.

An embarrassment.  Who is this game for? 

Not worth your time.  There are better versions of this game available for far less. 

6/10.

This "definitive" edition is anything but. The graphics are a bit better, but nothing is playing right. Everything is a bit off when playing this game. Units don't really obey your commands. This kinda sucks to be honest, I really don't know how you can't upgrade a game this old and simple and mess it up, but here we are.

[H1] Cash-grab, not a labour of love [/h1]
64 bit integration is a fantastic addition, and there are lofty promises of mod support and tools (that have yet to be materialised). Despite the 64 bit, the game runs poorly and there doesn't seem to have been any improvements to performance. Game is riddled with bugs and issues that never existed in the originals. Bug-fixing lists issues as solved, only for them to remain or worsen after yet another patch.
[h3] A plethora of bugs [/h3]
[list]
[*]Units barely doing damage while pursuing moving targets
[*]Transports leaving units stranded on impassable terrain
[*]Grenade abilities that end up doing nothing
[*]Questionable AI pathing
[*]Flickering textures
[*]Broken campaign AI
[*]Jump units fail to do so, but use up their "energy", or are returned to where they started.
[*]Unit portraits flicker between new additions and old shitty upscaled versions
[*]Sync-kills on units that aren't supposed to happen (Squiggoth sync-killing a rhino transport like it was infantry)
[/list]
To name a few.
[h3] Cheap AI upscale [/h3]
Lazy upscaling, applied haphazardly to all the textures in the game, seems to have been little to no quality control as the textures are everything from good looking, to mediocre, to oddly washed out and produces a jarring visual mess on certain unit models. Unit portraits were released in such a poor state that they looked worse than the originals, and have subsequently been updated post-launch after having taken our money.
[h3] Busted campaigns [/h3]
[list]
[*]Soulstorm campaigns are missing their ending cinematics
[*]Patches have repeatedly bricked and bugged out old saves
[*]Currently the Dark Crusade campaign AI does nothing but idle
[*]Iconic voice lines and quips during stronghold missions cut short by unit response sounds
[*]In-game cinematics failing to animate properly due to bugs
[*]Game breaking bugs barring progress in the original DoW campaign because of a bug related to jumping units
[/list]
[h3] That was then, this is now [/h3]
Currently, as it stands, this version of DoW is a hard pass. It remains to be seen if the developers stick to this game for long enough to iron out all the bugs and perhaps improve performance. A more apt name would be "definitively broken edition". The few improvements provided do not make up for the additional bugs, and the frustrating experience of playing the campaigns during these rounds of patches that break your progress. Clearly Relic is only interested in fleecing its fans with releasing anniversary editions and now lazy "definitive" editions in quick succession for DoW and Space Marine. So far, neither provide a "definitive" version of the game to play, but are instead splitting the already small player-base further.
Still able to shoot through cover, crappy graphics, and janky controls. Why the hell did I purchase this game again?

UHHH kinda been on the fence with this one, on one hand experiencing the 40K universe here isn't bad, and gives a true look into the armies of the universe providing lots of fun, on the other hand they fumbled this "definitive edition" as bad as WarCraft 3 fumbled its "REFORGED" edition. The path tracing is absolute crap and leads to more problems than not, like the Tau (who have immense range) shooting through solid walls they and mountains shouldn't be able to and still dealing full damage. The devs are fully reliant upon users reporting bugs, as it seems like their list of "known issues" dwindles while many still remain present in the game. Like the one i just mentioned which hasn't been fixed in their most recent patch or brought up on their "known issues" which is also a pain to find as they have several links for it but none actually lead you to the the forum, you can only see it if you view their most recent patch notes and looks at the bottom.

Allied Teammates have no coordination between each other and often you cannot run a quick start game in skirmish (PvAI) due to the inherent incompetence of the allies who run early assaults on enemy bases and lose their troops only to get annihilated while you're still waiting for troops spawn. This happens no matter what difficulty you play on and the AI never attempts to rebuild that initial force in full. This essentially forces you to babysit allied AI so they have a fighting chance against enemy AI which coordinates assaults perfectly. I absolutely love RTS games and this one is good, but the bugs do not help with wanting to play the campaign (which is missing specific cutscenes) or relax on single player skirmish. Which leads to the multiplayer which is fun but if you've ever played an RTS you'd know the sweat is so real it seethes through your screen from the enemy player.

If they end up fixing the game it might be worth the buy, but as it stands i currently regret my purchase and inability to refund because of too much playtime.
